BTW, for symsqrt I've been using function below. No gradients, but will be after SVD gradients are supported as in #6503

def symsqrt(mat, eps=1e-7):
  """Symmetric square root."""
  s, u, v = tf.svd(mat)
  # sqrt is unstable around 0, just use 0 in such case
  si = tf.where(tf.less(s, eps), s, tf.sqrt(s))
  return u @ tf.diag(si) @ tf.transpose(v)

If you just want to whiten data, and backprop through it, you can use Cholesky.
Whitening is accomplished by using modified Cholesky Decomposition which is just a couple of arithmetic ops on top of Cholesky, here's a mini tutorial

BTW, for symsqrt I've been using function below. No gradients, but will be after SVD gradients are supported as in https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/6503

```
def symsqrt(mat, eps=1e-7):
  """Symmetric square root."""
  s, u, v = tf.svd(mat)
  # sqrt is unstable around 0, just use 0 in such case
  si = tf.where(tf.less(s, eps), s, tf.sqrt(s))
  return u @ tf.diag(si) @ tf.transpose(v)
```
If you just want to whiten data, and backprop through it, you can use Cholesky.
Whitening is accomplished by using modified Cholesky Decomposition which is just a couple of arithmetic ops on top of Cholesky, here's a [mini tutorial](https://wolfr.am/lbQxdRUK)
